com.artisan.powerhooks

Class PowerHookVariable

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.artisan.powerhooks.PowerHook
      • com.artisan.powerhooks.PowerHookVariable

  • public class PowerHookVariable
extends com.artisan.powerhooks.PowerHook
    Represents an Artisan Power Hook Variable.

    A PowerHookVariable is a variable you would like to use in your app whose value is configurable from Artisan Tools.

    You don't need to instantiate this class yourself, but will see instances of this if you call PowerHookManager.getAllVariables() or PowerHookManager.getPowerHookVariable(String)

    SAMPLE USAGE: (from SampleActivity) 
     public class SampleActivity extends ArtisanActivity {
 
        private PowerHookVariable mPowerHookVariable;
 
        @Override
        protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
                super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
                setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);
 
                mPowerHookVariable = PowerHookManager.getPowerHookVariable("startScreenText");
 
                // ...other onCreate code...
        }
 }

    • Method Detail

      • getValue

        public java.lang.String getValue()
        Get the current value for this Power Hook.

        This is equivalent to calling PowerHookManager.getVariableValue(String) for this Power Hook and will always return the same value.
        Returns:
        the current value for this Power Hook.

      • onPowerHookChanged

        public void onPowerHookChanged(android.app.Activity activity,
                      com.artisan.powerhooks.PowerHookCallback callback)
        Register a callback which will be executed on the UI thread when this Power Hook value changes.

        We recommend that you call this method in onCreate, onStart or onResume.

        NOTE: The thread calling the block of code is guaranteed to be the main thread. If the code inside of the block requires executing on a background thread you will need to implement this logic.

        IMPORTANT: As long as this callback is registered it will be called, even if the Activity is no longer visible. Depending on your execute method's implementation this may have undesirable effects. For this reason we have provided an unregisterPowerHookChanged() method which will deactivate and remove the callback.

        SAMPLE USAGE: (from SampleActivity) 
         @Override
 protected void onStart() {
        super.onStart();
 
        TextView startScreenTextView = (TextView) findViewById(R.id.activity_text);
        startScreenTextView.setText(mPowerHookVariable.getValue());
 
        mPowerHookVariable.onPowerHookChanged(this, new PowerHookCallback() {
                @Override
                public void execute(boolean previewMode) {
                        TextView startScreenTextView = (TextView) SampleActivity.this.findViewById(R.id.activity_text);
                        startScreenTextView.setText(mPowerHookVariable.getValue());
                }
        });
 }
        NOTE: previewMode is a feature that hasn't been rolled out for the Android SDK yet and will always be false until it is added.
        Parameters:
        activity - A reference to the Activity that should be used to execute this callback. We will execute the callback on the ui thread from this Activity.
        callback - a callback to execute when this Power Hook value changes.

      • unregisterPowerHookChanged

        public void unregisterPowerHookChanged()
        This method should be called in onPause, onStop or onDestroy to remove the callback that you registered for this Power Hook variable. You may call this sooner if you wish to remove your callback.

        The method that you call this in should be the parallel to the method where the callback was registered, so if you registered in onResume then you should unregister in onPause.

        If you have not registered a callback then this method will be ignored.

        SAMPLE USAGE: (from SampleActivity) 
         @Override
 protected void onStop() {
        super.onStop();
        mPowerHookVariable.unregisterPowerHookChanged();
 }

      • powerHookValueUpdatedFromPlaylist

        public void powerHookValueUpdatedFromPlaylist(com.artisan.otto.event.PowerHookVariableUpdatedEvent event)
        This is an internal method. It is automatically called when new Power Hook values arrive from the Artisan servers. You do not need to call this method. Instead, if you are interested in being notified when new Power Hook values arrive you should register a callback with onPowerHookChanged(Activity, PowerHookCallback).
